Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Resolving Astrophysical Water Formation Pathways on Dust Grain Surfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dust grains in cold interstellar gas clouds provide sites for chemical reactions of simple atoms and molecules. Reactions on dust grains can produce molecules such as water, which is one of nature's most important compounds, and is essential to life as we currently know it. This research project will use advanced experimental techniques to study how water forms on cold surfaces similar to those of dust grains in space. Results from the study will help astronomers understand how processes on interstellar dust grains can produce water in space. Understanding these processes could also allow astronomers to understand the origins of Earth's water. The project, conducted at an undergraduate institution with a largely Hispanic student body, will train students in methods of advanced scientific research.

The principal investigator will undertake laboratory studies of water formation on cold surfaces to: (1) understand the predominant formation pathways of water on dust grains in cold molecular clouds and protoplanetary disks; and (2) explain the anomalously high 16-oxygen abundance in the Sun relative to the terrestrial planets. Specifically, the studies will gauge the relative importance of two water formation pathways --- H + oxygen and H + ozone --- by depositing H atoms and oxygen or ozone molecules on a cold surface and then analyzing the isotopic composition of the water molecules produced. This will be done using a cavity-ringdown spectrometer calibrated for isotopic analysis, allowing a direct measurement of the branching ratios of the reactions to within 1%. The investigator will conduct this project at an undergraduate institution with a predominantly Hispanic student body. This will allow him to provide training in laboratory astrophysics to students from diverse backgrounds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:  A fundamental puzzle in the solar system's formation is understanding why the terrestrial planets, comets, and asteroids are depleted in an isotope of oxygen ( 16O) compared to the Sun.  Answering this puzzle has the promise of providing key insights into the formation history of the planets and this project's main goal was to understand what role, if any,  chemical reactions involving water played.  Our original focus, which was to make water using a high energy electron beam to break the chemical bonds holding together precursor molecules such as  H2 and O2 together changed once we realized that we may also break the oxygen bearing bonds (e.g. Si-O) of the solids directly underneath.  Thus, with the help of a new collaborator and the use of an NSF Instrument Facility at UCLA capable of measuring the relative abundances of oxygen atoms in the solids, we set out to answer this question.  As sometimes happens in science, in answering this unforeseen question we discovered an answer, perhaps the answer, to the big picture puzzle we were attempting to understand.   

As a result of this funding we have discovered that non-thermal oxygen isotope exchange between water ice and oxygen bearing solids imprints in the solids an isotopic signature that closely resembles the one that characterizes the planets, comets, asteroid, and the bulk of the terrestrial bodies in the solar system.   The conditions simulated in our experiments, combined with what is known about the cosmic ray environments of protoplanetary disks leads us to conclude that the planets may have acquired a similar signature during the formation of the solar system in the outer parts of the solar system.  Here, water-ice covered dust grains would have been irradiated by solar cosmic ray protons (and electrons) and were likely to have acquired their 16O depletion.   A paper describing this work will be submitted in the near future.

In addition to this main accomplishment, we also developed new collaborations.  Using the apparatus that was partially funded by this grant, we have done the first measurements of liquid water found in a primitive meteorite (Zag) that is 4.5 billion years old.  These measurements are fundamentally interesting as they provide tight constraints on the origins of water in the solar system, including Earth.  This work has been presented at various conferences and a publication  is in progress.  If it had not been for the pandemic closing off access to the lab, this manuscript would likely have been completed before the close of this grant.

In thinking about performing mathematical modeling of the laboratory experiments, I realized that a simple approach to astrochemical modeling could be used to understand or constrain the volatile ice (such as water) abundances of planetary systems.  This work was published as a major publication in 2020 although the bulk of the work occurred during the PIs sabbatical leave, which was partially funded by this NSF grant. 

Broader outcomes:  The broader impacts of funding this research have been significant.  In addition to fostering new collaborations and opportunities for the PI and undergraduate students at CSUSM, the science funded by this grant provided the motivation or organizing theme for significant professional development opportunities for students who are traditionally underrepresented in the sciences including at least 5 female physics/chemistry majors, and 4 Latino/Latina Physics majors.  Included in these professional development opportunities include opportunities to present at undergraduate research conferences (local and regional) as well as national and international conferences and regular opportunities to discuss scientific research and challenges during our weekly/bi-weekly group meetings.  The vast majority of the students directly and indirectly supported by this grant gone on to have careers in industry as engineers or to graduate school in related fields (e.g. Applied Physics, Earth and Space Sciences, Electrical Engineering).  The one exception, a female Latina physicist and recent graduate,  is now planning to return to school to pursue a masters in physics degree by applying to the American Physical Society's (APS) Bridge program.  She is second-author on a manuscript under review by a major research journal.

The PI of this grant is a first-generation Mexican-American college graduate and benefited significantly from the funding provided by NSF.  In addition to the refereed and non-refereed publications to be produced from this grant's funding, the PI also was able to attend workshops and conferences that he would not have been able to attend otherwise.  These include the Gordon Origins of Solar Systems Workshop (2019), American Astronomical Society (AAS, 2018, 2019) meetings, and the Lunar and Planetary Science Conference (LPSC) conferences.   These opportunities have led to new funded and unfunded ollaborations, including one to build a planetary exploration instrument.  The extra sabbatical time funded by this grant continues to pay dividends in the form of expanded research ideas, opportunities for students and the PI, and collaborations.
